Description: check internet connection via ethernet
StepDescription: Ensure ethernet cable is connceted to Internet
Plug the other port to IoT device
Check if wget http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/bluetooth/bluez-5.30.tar.xz
ExpectedResult: wget command works

Description: use gatttool to write IoT BLE handle value
StepDescription: IoT device does ble advertising. Command is: hciconfig hci0 leadv
On Host, gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --characteristics

In the characteristics list, use a handle to see its value. Command is:
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-read -a <handle>

Write new value into the handle by:
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-write-req -a <handle> -n abcd
ExpectedResult: return write success

StepDescription:
Read this handle again.
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-read -a <handle>
ExpectedResult: the value has been modified to 'ab cd ...'

Description: connect rs232 cable for debugging
StepDescription: Plug RS232 cable to the main-board
Check by minicom on PC to get the debugging output
ExpectedResult: info could be output on minicom

Description: Plug usb port to IoT and plug rs232 to PC
StepDescription: Plug usb port to IoT device
plug rs232 (with rs232-com cable) to the COM of PC
Run serial-test (source code is in attachment of the feature 381) on IoT device: serial-test /dev/ttyUSB0
On the other part, plug the serial port to a PC, launch COM1 with 115200. Enter YooHoo
ExpectedResult: minicom echoes "2U2".

Description: The product shall run on a VirtualBox VM
StepDescription: put vdi image in virtualbox and run sanity test cases
ExpectedResult: No specific bugs for virtualbox

Description: To check CI shall provide a source archive for Ostro releases
StepDescription: Check meta-ostro/conf/distro/ostro.conf has configuration about PREMIRRORS(SOURCE_MIRROR_URL)
ExpectedResult: Has this configuration

StepDescription: Check the archive source are located in SOURCE_MIRROR_URL
ExpectedResult: See archived source code in the url

Description: To check if user can build app in Ostro

StepDescription: according to build instrumentation in README, do make/make check/make install

ExpectedResult: the source repo can be downloaded with git

StepDescription: build with -g option
ExpectedResult: the application can be built successfully

StepDescription: debug with"gdb <app> "; set break point; list codes and variables; step into libs...
ExpectedResult: the gdb can be used to debug applications

Description: To check if user can debug app with valgrind in Ostro
StepDescription: boot up Ostro and use "git clone <project URL>" to get some project codes into Ostro
ExpectedResult: the source repo can be downloaded with git

StepDescription: build with -g option
ExpectedResult: the application can be built successfully

StepDescription: run app with valgrind: "valgrind --tool=memcheck --leak-check=full <app> "to check memory leak
ExpectedResult: there app memory use report shows on console

Description: To check dev image is bootable and SSH/serial/system log ready
StepDescription: Download dev image and install it on P1 platforms to check it can boot successfully
ExpectedResult: dev image boot successfully

StepDescription: Check SSH connection to Ostro
ExpectedResult: Ostro can be connected successfully; no further setup need

StepDescription: Check serial port connection to Ostro
ExpectedResult: Ostro can be connected successfully; no further setup need

StepDescription: Check system log enabled in Ostro: a. /run/log/journal; b. run command "journalctl"
ExpectedResult: the system log tool and folder should be in and user can use journalctl to check logs

Description: To check the Instruction correctness
StepDescription: Check the doc mentioned in this Requirement
ExpectedResult: The doc instruction is correct

Description: To check the Instruction correctness
StepDescription: make sure platform description is accurate and the links provided are correct
ExpectedResult: The doc is correct

Description: Use soletta node type API to find single oic resource
StepDescription: Put 3 test files ('light-client.fbp', 'light-server.fbp' and 'sol-flow.json' from soletta source src/examples/flow/oic/) to IoT device /home/root/ folder.

In the IoT device, it should be able to run fbp file. Then, run:
> export SOL_MACHINE_ID="580a3d6a9d194a23b90a24573558d2f4"
> ./light-server.fbp
ExpectedResult: The light-server is able to be setup. And no anything output.

StepDescription: In another terminal, run: ./light-client.fbp
ExpectedResult:
After client running, both client and server part will output continousely:
LightState true (boolean)
LightState false (boolean)

Description: Use soletta node type API to scan multiple oic resource
StepDescription: Put 2 test files ('light-scan/light-client-scan.fbp' and 'light-scan/sol-flow.json' from soletta source src/examples/flow/oic/) to IoT device /home/root/ folder.
Put light-server.fbp to at least 2 IoT devices.

In the 2 IoT devices, start light-server with different id:
> export SOL_MACHINE_ID="580a3d6a9d194a23b90a24573558d2f4"
> ./light-server.fbp
ExpectedResult: On 2 devices, the light-server is able to be setup. And no anything output.

StepDescription: In another terminal, run: ./light-client-scan.fbp to scan all resources.
ExpectedResult: The 2 light-server should be found.

Description: Install eSDK on host machine (host OS: Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, CentOS, OpenSUSE)

Description: Build ostro image with default configuration from eSDK

StepDescription: run "devtool build-image ostro-image" to build out ostro image

Description: Add source and build application in eSDK
StepDescription: run "devtool add {testapp recipe} {test recipe source tree}

StepDescription: edit the appended recipe about how to build and installation parts, then run "devtool {testapp}" command
ExpectedResult: the testapp can be built out by eSDK.

Description: update eSDK

Description: build uninative tarball
StepDescription: fetch ostro-os source codes and build uninative tarball with command: bitbake uninative-tarball
check the correct 64bit/32bit source can be fetched and uninative tarball can be built out
ExpectedResult: when fetch source codes, you can check the checksum (stored in meta/conf/distro/include/yocto-uninative.inc) according to build machine arch; and the "uninative-tarball" folder created under build/tmp-glibc/work/<build-machine-arch>

Description: check the uninative can be deployed
StepDescription: clean up the sstate: e.g. rm build/sstate-cache
build image or project with "bitbake <i.e. ostro-image or soletta>"
ExpectedResult: after build done,"in the build/sstate-cache", there is "universal" folder, which including the "-native" package cache

Description: check the uninative can be deployed
StepDescription: clean up the sstate: e.g. rm build/sstate-cache
set up "SSTATE_MIRROR ?= file://.* http://download.ostroproject.org/sstate/ostro-os/PATH" in build/conf/local.conf
build image or project with "bitbake <i.e. ostro-mage or soletta>"
ExpectedResult: after build done,in the build/sstate-cache, there is "universal" folder. However, no "-native" package cache in the folder at all.

Description: Full update using swupd
StepDescription: use "swupd verify" to make sure current flashed image is in good status for swupdate
ExpectedResult: no error should be shown in log

StepDescription: do repo validation using blackbox tool or other tool at client side, verify repo is correct
ExpectedResult: repo should be correct

StepDescription: apply update task using "swupd_update -v -c" and make sure update complete successfully, this will redownload the update repo
ExpectedResult: the update should complete successfully and corresponding files are changed

StepDescription: do "swupd verify" to check system is correct
ExpectedResult: check system should be in good status

Description: check if the multilib can be built by ostro build environment
StepDescription: get the ostro-os git repo
add "require conf/ostro-multilib.conf" to your build/conf/local.conf, then build ostro-image
ExpectedResult: the ostro-image can be built successfully

Description: check if Ostro supports secure boot
StepDescription: Create and sign certificates; install signing key to bios following the docs fom ostroproject/meta-ostro/blob/master/doc/howtos/uefi-secure-boot.rst
Boot an unsigned image (default)
ExpectedResult: "image fails to boot: ""Invalid signature detected. Check Secure Boot Policy in Setup"""

Description: check if Ostro supports secure boot
StepDescription: Create and sign certificates; install signing key to bios following the docs fom ostroproject/meta-ostro/blob/master/doc/howtos/uefi-secure-boot.rst
Generate a new key and sign an image with this key
ExpectedResult: signing succeeds

StepDescription: try to boot the image
ExpectedResult: image fails to boot: "Invalid signature detected. Check Secure Boot Policy in Setup"

Description: check if Ostro supports secure boot
StepDescription: Create and sign certificates; install signing key to bios following the docs fom ostroproject/meta-ostro/blob/master/doc/howtos/uefi-secure-boot.rst
Sign an image with the initially generated key
ExpectedResult: signing succeeds

StepDescription: try to boot the image
ExpectedResult: the ostro-image boots successfully

Description: edit/run fbp file in soletta-dev-app

start up soletta-dev-app server: "$ systemctl start soletta-dev-app-server.service"
ExpectedResult: "check the server started by ""$ ps | grep node""; there should be a node process started"

StepDescription: launch a web browser in another host machine, i.e. chrome or firefox; and input address: http://<ostro-ip-addres>:<port>

StepDescription: in "code viewer" area to edit fbp file like: _(timer:interval=1000) OUT -> IN _(boolean/toggle:initial_state=true) OUT -> IN _(console)

StepDescription: click run button on the top-right
ExpectedResult: "the fbp app is running and run log print in a pop up window"

StepDescription: click Close button in run window
ExpectedResult: "the fbp app will be stopped soon"

start up soletta-dev-app server: "$ systemctl start soletta-dev-app-server.service"

start up soletta-dev-app server: "$ systemctl start soletta-dev-app-server.service"

ExpectedResult: "the text file can be import into ""code viewer"" area"

StepDescription: select a configuration JSON file (i.e. sol-flow-intel-minnow-max-linux_gt_3_17.json) on top-right drop-down list; the click run button
ExpectedResult: "the syntax error mark removed and the fbp app can be run"

Description: check if ostro-os project involve meta-soletta layer
StepDescription: check ostro-os has integrated meta-soletta project and layer: ostro-os/meta-soletta; ostro-os/conf/combo-layer.conf
ExpectedResult: relevant meta-soletta should be existed

Description: Ostro OS repo should support create recipe based on CMakeFile.txt
StepDescription: get ostro-os repo and run "source oe-init-build-env" to setup build environment
run command: devtool add soletta-demos "git://github.com/solettaproject/soletta-demos"
ExpectedResult: "there is a recipe generated successfully"

StepDescription: check recipe according to soletta-demos/CMakeLists.txt
ExpectedResult: "the depdencies in CMakeLists.txt should be detected or listed in recipe ""DEPENDS = "" "

Description: Ostro OS repo should handle node.js module (NPM) dependency fetch
StepDescription: get ostro-os repo and run "source oe-init-build-env" to setup build environment
run command: devtool add npm-forever "npm://registry.npmjs.org;name=forever;version=0.15.1"
ExpectedResult: "there is a node.js module recipe generated successfully"

StepDescription: build the module by "bitbake npm-forever"
ExpectedResult: "it can build node.js module successfully and no need to fetch dependency npm package out of bitbake process "

Description: Ostro OS repo should detect all mandatory and optional dependencies defined in configure.in/ac
StepDescription: get ostro-os repo and run "source oe-init-build-env" to setup build environment
run command: devtool add powertop "git://github.com/fenrus75/powertop"
ExpectedResult: "there is a powertop recipe generated successfully"

StepDescription: check recipe powertop and comparing to the configure.ac in powertop git repo
ExpectedResult: "the dependencies can be detected or listed in ""DEPENDS ="" "

Description: check devtool has easy way to create kernel recipe
StepDescription: get ostro-os repo and run "source oe-init-build-env" to setup build environment
run command "devtool kernel-menuconfig" to update kernel configure
ExpectedResult: "the kernel recipe in ostro-os/meta/recipes-kernel/linux can be updated based on srctree/.config"

Description: check how to build off-tree kernel module
StepDescription: get ostro-os repo and run "source oe-init-build-env" to setup build environment

create sample kernel module source: a. $mkdir /tmp/hellomod; b. $cp ostro-os/meta/lib/oeqa/runtime/files/hellomod.c /tmp/hellomod/; c. cp ostro-os/meta/lib/oeqa/runtime/files/hellomod_makefile /tmp/hellomod/Makefile
run command "devtool add hellomod /tmp/hellomod"
ExpectedResult: "the kernel module ""hellomod"" recipe can be created"

StepDescription: run command "bitbake hellomod"
ExpectedResult: "the kernel module ""hellomod.ko"" can be built successfully in /tmp/hellomod"

Description: check if there is mechanism to list bundle contents from YP/bitbake

check if there are different packages listed in different manifest file. And the refererence bundle image should include the least packages

Description: check use added package can be listed
StepDescription: edit ostro-image-swupd.bb to add one package into BUNDLE_CONTENTS[<bundle-name>]
then try to use bitbake build swupd image
ExpectedResult: check if the image manifest file list the user-added package

Description: check image does not include packages under GPLv3 relevant license

run "./utils/test_gplv3_free_image.sh <image manifest file>"

Description: Check the node module mqtt can be installed via npm

ExpectedResult: The npm can connect network

Description: Check the node module coap can be installed via npm
